question: Kimberly? It's Dad.
answer: Hey, Dad. What's up?

question: Your car's leaking either transmission or brake fluid. I want you to have it checked ASAP at a gas station.
answer: You got it, Dad. I'll call you if I have a problem.

question: I mean it. Take care of it.
answer: I will, Dad. Bye, luv you.

question: Tell me again how it started.
answer: Like I said, it was like I was there. I remember everything. The sounds of the crashes, the smells, the look on Shaina's face...

question: Do you remember what triggered it all?
answer: The log truck...and everybody I guess. Everyone was driving like a maniac. And somehow I knew something horrible was going to happen, even before it did.

question: You knew? You just mean a hunch, right? A bad vibe, maybe?
answer: More than that. All the songs on the radio were about car crashes. Some kid's banging toy cars together. She was dialing her cell phone with her headset on. His car was leaking oil all over the road.

question: Billboards about accidents. Kids yelling "pile up" for no reason. It all felt...just wrong. Just like...
answer: Like what?

question: I know this sounds crazy...but you all heard about Flight 180, right? The kid who got off the plane?
answer: You mean Alex Browning.

question: Ooooh, I see it now. Your future... A transfer to another department.
answer: You've made your point.

question: Good. Cause we just got some new info and I don't ne ed you getting freaky on me.
answer: What?

question: Come on, Tim, lights out already.
answer: Mom?

question: Yeah?
answer: You think... You think those guys were b.s.-ing us today or what?

question: It's okay, Dad. I'm not ten anymore.
answer: I'm sorry. I'm just so happy that you're safe.

question: I love you too, Dad. Goodnight.
answer: You know, after your mother died... There were so many times I didn't think I could last another day. I can't even tell you some of the

question: I used to have those feelings, too. But that's when I'd think of Mom. Her strength...and courage. And I'd pray that maybe I'd grow up to be as brave as she was. And the bad thoughts would go away.
answer: I don't know what I'd do if I lost you.

question: ...at the request of the patient, you are to relinquish any sharp objects such as nail files, pencils, pens, safety pins, bobby pins, no matches, lighters, belts, belt buckles, earrings, chokers, shoelaces... ...paper clips, watches, food, drinks, keys, poisons, pills and medications. You have a cell phone on you? Then I think we're all done.
answer: Wait. Is she...dangerous or something?

question: No honey, but she expects you are.
answer: Jesus, how long are you going to keep her locked up this way?

question: Depends on her, I guess. She's voluntary.
answer: Clear Rivers?

question: Clear Rivers?
answer: Kimberly Burroughs, eh? What do you want?

question: I thought...I thought you might be able to help me.
answer: Yeah, how?

question: I had a premonition about the Route 18 pile up. .. I saved some people. And now I think Death is after me.
answer: Nice work. Maybe if you're real lucky, you'll wind up in here with me. But I doubt you'll survive that long.

question: It's not just about me. Someone I saved died last night in a freak accident. What if the others are in danger, too?
answer: Well, if you put them on the list, they're already tits up.

question: What list?
answer: Death's list. The precise order you're going to die in. The survivors of Flight 180 died in the exact order they were originally meant to die in the plane crash. That was Death's original design.

question: Exact order? Then I'm next! I was meant to die with my friends, so I'm next!
answer: But you said someone else died last night. That means Death skipped past you. Someone must have intervened. Sometime yesterday you must have nearly died, but someone saved you.

question: Officer Burke pulled me away from the crash that killed my friends.
answer: Congratufuckinglations. That makes you last to go. But don't worry, once the others are dead, it'll come back for you. Always does.

question: That still doesn't make sense. You said you die in the same order you were originally meant to. But Evan Shaeffer died last in my premonition, not first.
answer: It's moving backwards? Are you sure?

question: Yes. In my premonition that Nora woman and her kid died first, then Evan and then...my friends.
answer: Backwards...that's new. That's good. Get all your tears out now, you'll need your eyes. For the signs.

question: Signs?
answer: If you have the same power as Alex, you'll be seeing signs soon. When you see anything creepy or ominous, an in-your- face irony kinda thing? Don't ignore it. It usually means the difference between life and death.

question: The songs on the radio. But wait. I don't understand. Why is this even happening to me?
answer: That's what Alex used to ask himself right up until...

question: It's obvious you know what you're talking about. You beat it. You have to help us.
answer: I didn't beat it; I hid from it. If you were smart you'd put a down payment on a burial plot and say goodbye to the dog, because what little life you have left is over as you know it. Don't make new friends, don't fall in love, and don't ever bother trying to save others. That's the worst killer of them all.

question: How can you say that? What kind of monster are you?
answer: My family is dead. My friends are dead. And Alex... And yes, that's the blade of a fucking ceiling fan in his head.

question: Know what? I think you're a coward. I think you hide out in here because you're too damn bitter and selfish to care about another
answer: I tried calling last night but your father --

question: Evan Shaeffer's dead.
answer: I know. I've gotten calls all morning from everyone who was on the onramp. We're all meeting at my apartment tonight.

question: Then you believe all this?? That Death is working off a list?
answer: I didn't. Until I was dispatched to clean up one of the Flight 180 survivors.

question: Clean up? I don't... Pigeons... It's a sign! If Clear's right about the order, then Nora and Tim are going to be attacke d by Pigeons!
answer: I'm not following you --

question: You think the tooth fairy's gonna come tonight? I'm thinkin' like fifteen bucks.
answer: Nice try, kiddo.

question: Mom! You okay?
answer: Sure hon. I'm fine. Let's shake it, we're late.

question: Nora's not coming. She refuses to leave her son.
answer: We have to tell her she's in danger!

question: I did. And right now, I don't think she cares.
answer: It's happening again. It's fucking But we're all going to die. We can't stop it. It's just a matter of time. I'm so scared.

question: I am too. But you can use that fear. It'll sharpen your instincts. Keep you alert fro signs. It's the only way you'll be able to sav e the others...and me. I know you didn't ask for any of this, Kimberly. But I don't think you have it in you to quit either.
answer: Clear/Thomas. Thomas/Clear. The second one just dies. A 16 year old kid.

question: Come to... Pick my brain? Flesh and bone require 1,600 degrees for cremation. Gold, prosthetics and other metals must be removed before the final --
answer: Just a simple question and we'll leave you alone with your new friend.

question: Fire away.
answer: How do you cheat Death once and for all?

question: Dead. But still fresh.
answer: Look, we drove a long way to get here. So if you happen to know how to get this death monkey off our backs, it sure would be swell if you told us.

question: For what purpose? You seek a back way out of a room with but one door. You can't cheat Death; there
answer: Bullshit. You told me Death has a distinct design, a blueprint, unalterable. But Alex and I cheated Death not once, but dozens of times. If the design is flawed, it can be beaten.

question: Such fire in you now. People are always most alive just before they die. Don't you think?
answer: It can be beaten. And you know it.

question: You have to tell us now. You're strong. Do you hear me? You're a fucking warrior. Nothing scares you. In fact you happen to be the single most powerful woman on earth. Now what did you see?
answer: I was driving a white van. It must've gone out of control because it crashed into a lake and I drowned. It was...horrible.

question: You were there?
answer: I can practically taste the water in my throat. And something else. The smell of flowers...

question: Shit, I don't have her number. She was never interviewed. She took off right after the accident.
answer: How are we going to find her? There must be thousands of white vans in this state.

question: Hey, I'm a police officer, remember?
answer: Oh God...

question: I, uh...sorry.
answer: I know, I know. We need my eyes.

question: Got it.
answer: I don't get it. Why is everything happening so fast? After Flight 180. A month went by before anyone died. And now five people are dead in less than a day.

question: Here we go. The vehicle's a delivery van registered to Jorge and Isabella Cruz. And Christ, there's almost a dozen domestic disturbance complaints on these two.
answer: We need to hurry.

question: Let's lay this on her gently now. The stress alone could upset the pregnancy.
answer: What?

question: I'm Officer Burke. I'm looking for an Isabella Cruz.
answer: Shut up!!!

question: Are you Jorge Cruz?
answer: Maybe. What's this about?

question: May we come in?
answer: No. What's this about?

question: It's about your wife, Isabella. Now is she here?
answer: No. I'm alone.

question: Look, pal, it's probably nothing. But I need to see --
answer: Forget it. You'll need a warrant. I know, I'm a lawyer. Stop!!! You can't go in there!!! I'm going to sue your ass!

question: Forget it. You'll need a warrant. I know, I'm a lawyer. Stop!!! You can't go in there!!! I'm going to sue your ass!
answer: Whose blood is that on the floor?

question: Mine, you idiot. The dog went nuts this afternoon. Now arrest her!
answer: Where's Isabella? Did you finally kill her you fucking wife beater?

question: We had a fight. Some things got broken, the dog went crazy, she left me. Wouldn't say where she was going.
answer: What was the fight about?

question: Take a guess.
answer: Does she have a cell phone? A way we can contact her?

question: Where are you going, Nora? You okay?
answer: Four years ago my husband died. Now Tim. There's nothing left for me.

question: Don't say that. Once you lose hope, it's already too late.
answer: If it's my time to go, to be in heaven with my family, then I can accept that.

question: You can't give up. Don't accept Death's plan. Trust me, you can fight this. If we can just survive long enough until that baby is born, we can --
answer: If you'll excuse me, I have a funeral to prepare.

question: Going down, right? Um, by the way, your shoe's untied. Probably for you, anyway.
answer: Officer Burke? I can't hear...

question: What is it? What's wrong?
answer: Let me go let me go!

question: Can I ask you a question?
answer: Sure.

question: When I die. Is it gonna hurt?
answer: I...I don't know.

question: And you're gonna die after me, right?
answer: I guess so.

question: What do you mean "grand theft auto?" This is insane.
answer: Hopefully the district judge can straighten it all out by Monday mor ning.

question: Jorge. When I get out of here I'm going to sue his cheating ass off.
answer: Are you kidding me?! Oh, man. C'mon. Let's go. Damn, they always stick me with the clunker.

question: I never mad it. The Greyhound bus I was on splattered some chick all over the road and we had to stop.
answer: Was that in Mt. Abraham?

question: Yeah. How did you know?
answer: That bus you were on? It killed Terry Mathers. She was supposed to die on Flight 180.

question: It's all starting to come together. When Alex got us off Flight 180, it didn't just change our lives. It
answer: I'm not sure I understand.

question: Being alive after our time caused an outward ripple - a rift in Death's design.
answer: So if you never got off the plane, none of us would be ali ve in the first place.

question: What are you doing? You're going to kill us!
answer: No. If anyone dies from a crash now, it'll be me. But I can't die if Eugene and Isabella are still alive. I'm last on Death's list.

question: Are you crazy? What makes you think you'd survive?
answer: What happened when Eugene tried to kill himself out of turn?

question: Six duds in a row.
answer: And when it was Rory's turn to die, and Thomas was in the way?

question: I was dead. And came back to life. An EEG machine. Where's Eugene?
answer: But it's over. Isabella's baby was the key. You saw her die and everything, right?

question: I don't...what if I made a mistake?
answer: Impossible. She was on the onramp.

question: I'm not sure... I don't think Isabella was ever destined to die in the pile -up.
answer: Then what's the premonition of the lake supposed to mean?

question: Can you remember anything about it?
answer: ...the Same hands from the van.

question: It's you Kimberly. The premonitions are about you.
answer: No! It can't be.

question: Nurse Kalarjian... Oh my God. That's it. The lake. The EEG machine. Nurse Kalarjian.
answer: What?

question: You can't cheat destiny. I know what I have to do to save us. I have to die.
answer: That's crazy. You can't give up now. We can still fight this thing.
